propositions.text: The Community MusicWorks Center in Providence, Rhode Island, was built almost entirely from cross-laminated timber (CLT) and glulam
propositions.sourceText: When a visionary music nonprofit for youth in Providence, Rhode Island, set out to build a single dedicated facility, the architects at 3SIX0 responded with a crystalline structure at the intersection of two city grids—and built almost entirely from cross-laminated timber (CLT) and glulam. More than just an innovative structural...

propositions.text: Concrete and steel were initially assumed to be the most affordable construction systems for the Community MusicWorks Center project
propositions.sourceText: Though concrete and steel were initially assumed to be the most affordable construction systems, 3SIX0 and CMW soon shifted to a less obvious option: CLT. “Wood was in the air, but it was certainly not a foregone conclusion when we started,” Leski says. “This was always a budget-constrained project, always....

propositions.text: When budget numbers were first developed for the Community MusicWorks Center project, it was assumed it would be more affordable to build with conventional concrete and steel
propositions.sourceText: Though concrete and steel were initially assumed to be the most affordable construction systems, 3SIX0 and CMW soon shifted to a less obvious option: CLT. “Wood was in the air, but it was certainly not a foregone conclusion when we started,” Leski says. “This was always a budget-constrained project, always....

propositions.text: Cross-laminated timber (CLT) became a viable alternative for the Community MusicWorks Center project with support from the Healthy Materials Lab at Parsons School of Design and encouragement from local contractor Pezzuco Construction Inc.
propositions.sourceText: With support from the Healthy Materials Lab, a design research lab at Parsons School of Design, and encouragement from the local contractor, Pezzuco Construction Inc., CLT became a more than viable alternative. Not only did it offer speed of erection and lower carbon impact, but it also aligned with the...

propositions.text: Wood has resonance, unlike brick which is dead or glass which is sharp
propositions.sourceText: Beyond cultural resonance, the material also offered acoustic benefits. “Wood has this beautiful resonance—it’s not dead like brick and not sharp like glass,” Bardt continues. “It creates a warmth that feels right for a place built around sound and music. That resonance has to be shaped and controlled.”

propositions.text: Wood creates a warmth that feels right for a place built around sound and music, like the Community MusicWorks Center
propositions.sourceText: Beyond cultural resonance, the material also offered acoustic benefits. “Wood has this beautiful resonance—it’s not dead like brick and not sharp like glass,” Bardt continues. “It creates a warmth that feels right for a place built around sound and music. That resonance has to be shaped and controlled.”

propositions.text: The resonance of wood has to be shaped and controlled for acoustic purposes
propositions.sourceText: Beyond cultural resonance, the material also offered acoustic benefits. “Wood has this beautiful resonance—it’s not dead like brick and not sharp like glass,” Bardt continues. “It creates a warmth that feels right for a place built around sound and music. That resonance has to be shaped and controlled.”

propositions.text: The performance space at the Community MusicWorks Center vibrates with the energy of sound, thanks to the cross-laminated timber (CLT) and wood cladding
propositions.sourceText: When a visionary music nonprofit for youth in Providence, Rhode Island, set out to build a single dedicated facility, the architects at 3SIX0 responded with a crystalline structure at the intersection of two city grids—and built almost entirely from cross-laminated timber (CLT) and glulam. More than just an innovative structural...

propositions.text: Every room at the Community MusicWorks Center needed some level of acoustic isolation to avoid sound transference into and out of the performance spaces
propositions.sourceText: The acoustical considerations also extend beyond the central hall. “The performance space is very alive—it vibrates with the energy of sound, thanks to the CLT and wood cladding,” Leski says. But every other room needed some level of acoustic isolation to avoid sound transference into the performance spaces, and vice...

propositions.text: To achieve acoustic isolation at the Community MusicWorks Center, the team implemented double-wall construction

propositions.text: To achieve acoustic isolation at the Community MusicWorks Center, the team poured a light concrete topping on the cross-laminated timber (CLT) floors

propositions.text: Arup treated the performance hall at the Community MusicWorks Center like an instrument
propositions.sourceText: “Working with Arup, we treated the performance hall like an instrument,” Leski says. “Each surface was tuned to reflect, diffuse, or absorb sound.” The result is architecture that sounds as good as it looks.

propositions.text: Each surface in the performance hall at the Community MusicWorks Center was tuned to reflect, diffuse, or absorb sound
propositions.sourceText: “Working with Arup, we treated the performance hall like an instrument,” Leski says. “Each surface was tuned to reflect, diffuse, or absorb sound.” The result is architecture that sounds as good as it looks.

propositions.text: Wood is a very good material for music and acoustics because it resonates and vibrates with a more random distribution of frequency, according to Alban Bassuet, Associate Principal and Acoustical Engineering Consultant at Arup’s acoustics lab
propositions.sourceText: “When it comes to music and acoustics, wood is a very good material because it resonates and vibrates with a more random distribution of frequency. That’s what makes music so beautiful,” explains Alban Bassuet, Associate Principal and Acoustical Engineering Consultant at Arup’s acoustics lab.

propositions.text: In the performance hall at the Community MusicWorks Center, an optimization algorithm tested thousands of combinations of angled wood panels (concave, convex, and flat) to find the best arrangement for acoustics
propositions.sourceText: “In the performance hall, we ran an optimization algorithm that tested thousands of combinations of angled wood panels—concave, convex, and flat—to find the best arrangement for acoustics. And we raised the ceiling of the room as much as we could to reduce sound intensity.

propositions.text: The ceiling of the performance hall at the Community MusicWorks Center was raised as much as possible to reduce sound intensity
propositions.sourceText: “In the performance hall, we ran an optimization algorithm that tested thousands of combinations of angled wood panels—concave, convex, and flat—to find the best arrangement for acoustics. And we raised the ceiling of the room as much as we could to reduce sound intensity.

propositions.text: Wood comes with challenges, specifically controlling for vibration and sound isolation
propositions.sourceText: Nonetheless, wood comes with some challenges—specifically controlling for vibration and sound isolation. “We had to very carefully design all of the floors and ceilings to make sure adjacent activities would not disrupt other rooms. To achieve this in the practice rooms we built rooms within the CLT structure—a partial box-in-box...

propositions.text: Floors and ceilings at the Community MusicWorks Center had to be very carefully designed to ensure adjacent activities would not disrupt other rooms

To achieve this in the practice rooms we built rooms within the CLT structure—a partial box-in-box...

propositions.text: To achieve sound isolation in the practice rooms at the Community MusicWorks Center, rooms were built within the cross-laminated timber (CLT) structure using a partial box-in-box system as a relatively cost-effective isolation design strategy
propositions.sourceText: Nonetheless, wood comes with some challenges—specifically controlling for vibration and sound isolation. “We had to very carefully design all of the floors and ceilings to make sure adjacent activities would not disrupt other rooms. propositions.text: While all-mass-timber structures often take straightforward, orthogonal forms, the material can also tackle relatively complex geometries like the Community MusicWorks Center design
propositions.sourceText: While all-mass-timber structures often take straightforward, orthogonal forms, the material can also tackle relatively complex geometries like CMW’s design. That challenge, as Leski explains, revealed new possibilities for the material’s versatility—particularly in civic projects of this scale.

propositions.text: The Community MusicWorks Center design evolved into a hybrid system
propositions.sourceText: Initially envisioned as a pure CLT structure, the design evolved into a hybrid system—CLT slabs supported by glulam beams and columns. “Combining CLT and glulam with panelized light-frame wood construction kept things more affordable and also gave us greater flexibility,” Leski says. “And the quirks of the building’s geometry gave...

propositions.text: The hybrid system for the Community MusicWorks Center includes cross-laminated timber (CLT) slabs supported by glulam beams and columns
propositions.sourceText: Initially envisioned as a pure CLT structure, the design evolved into a hybrid system—CLT slabs supported by glulam beams and columns. “Combining CLT and glulam with panelized light-frame wood construction kept things more affordable and also gave us greater flexibility,” Leski says. “And the quirks of the building’s geometry gave...

propositions.text: Combining cross-laminated timber (CLT) and glulam with panelized light-frame wood construction kept the Community MusicWorks Center project more affordable

propositions.text: The walls of the performance hall at the Community MusicWorks Center are lined with exposed two-by-fours
propositions.sourceText: Even the performance hall’s interior finishes echo the project’s ethos. The walls are lined with exposed two-by-fours—simple, stick-frame construction, intentionally rough and rhythmic. “It almost evokes the idea of something under construction, not yet complete,” Leski explains. “This reflects that Community MusicWorks is a building of a community. It's an...

propositions.text: The abundant use of wood, exposed and textural, at the Community MusicWorks Center is both an aesthetic and philosophical gesture
propositions.sourceText: The abundant use of wood, exposed and textural, is both an aesthetic and philosophical gesture. “The rawness as a design language continues through, even in the most finished space,” Bardt adds. “What you see—exposed wood, unfinished edges, structural rhythm—reflects a philosophy.”
